Award.AwardTitle: Catalyzing a Cross-Disciplinary, Cross-University Urban Research Agenda in the Age of Digital Data

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Boston Area Research Initiative (BARI), a new entity based at Harvard's Radcliffe Institute for Advanced Study, proposes to catalyze and pursue a cross-disciplinary, cross-institutional urban research agenda that capitalizes on the data opportunity presented by the ongoing digital revolution. The proposed project will be organized around three main activities, each supported by BARI's rich network of data holders and users at Boston-area universities, public-sector agencies and private companies:

1) The identification and procurement of data that describe the people and places of the greater Boston area.
2) The support of original collaborative research by members of the BARI network that utilizes next-generation data in conjunction with traditional data sources and new methodologies.
3) The construction of a prototype Data Library that archives and catalogs both the data supporting the current research agenda, and the secondary data sets that emerge from their analysis, enabling future work and teaching applications to build off these initial projects.

Intellectual Merit

In recent years, many public and private institutions in cities have begun collecting administrative data from high to adequate quality, ranging from real-time descriptors of neighborhood conditions, to communication between individuals and movement between neighborhoods, to patterns in the education, health, and economic sectors. These next-generation data collectively provide a basis to create a comprehensive picture of human behavior in cities that has the potential to transform theoretical models of urban governance and behavior throughout the social, behavioral and economic sciences. BARI seeks to stimulate an urban research agenda that utilizes these data with a focus on three crosscutting themes:

1) Stability and change in neighborhoods, especially the social processes by which neighborhoods and their residents reciprocally shape each other across time.
2) The social structure of the city, or how interpersonal, attitudinal, and institutional relationships that cut across neighborhoods create an interlocking set of structures that potentially influence resource allocation and the way that neighborhoods operate.
3) Cognition and context, specifically how cognitive mechanisms and cultural narratives can drive behavior in urban neighborhoods, and the consequences those behaviors have for both the characteristics of a given neighborhood and its relationships with other neighborhoods.

The proposed agenda will be undertaken by BARI's leadership team, a set of experienced urban scholars at Harvard and Northeastern Universities, and the broader BARI network, which has over 100 members including faculty from ten Boston-area universities and experts from a range of government agencies and private companies. The project will also collaborate with initiatives in other cities, such as Chicago, and is designed to yield generalizable knowledge and portable methodological strategies.

Broader Impacts

The scholarly works that emerge from this project will contribute to the development of a computational social science that utilizes the rich content of next-generation data. Resulting insights will also provide the basis for teaching and policy innovations, with the translation from research to practice enhanced by BARI's already strong ties with the public sector. Finally, the efforts and products from the proposed project will pave the way for similar work in other cities and contribute to a comparative urban science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Boston Area Research Initiative (BARI) is a research coordination network (RCN) that brings together researchers, policymakers, and practitioners from across the greater Boston area to pursue collaborative urban research that advances both science and public policy. Over the course of the RCN grant, BARI catalyzed a cross-disciplinary, cross-institutional urban research agenda that capitalizes on the advent of modern digital (i.e., “big”) data by: 1) identifying and procuring new digital data sets of potential value for research, policy, and practice; 2) initiating and fostering collaborative research around these and other data; and 3) building the Boston Data Portal, where visitors can browse, map, analyze, and download research-quality data from various sources. Highlights include:

  • Initiating multiple lines of research, including the development and demonstration of methodological techniques that make modern digital data accessible for research, policy, and practice. For example, one paper measured physical disorder and deterioration (i.e., “broken windows”) from 311 reports, using it as a model for creating other ecometrics, or descriptors of neighborhood physical and social characteristics. This and other methodological advances have supported a series of substantive research projects arising over the course of the project including: 
    • Analysis of how Bostonians use the 311 system to maintain common spaces;
    • A test of broken windows theory using modern digital data that found that public disorder does not in fact lead to elevated crime in a neighborhood;
    • Efforts to leverage the geographically precise data of administrative records to identify and track “problem properties” that generate inordinate amounts of disorder and crime;
    • The use of social media data to measure  patterns of residential and social segregation;  
    • A collaboration with Boston Public Schools around the operation of their school lottery and assignment system.
  • Workshops and events to stimulate the growth and research activity of the community, including a full-day event in December of 2014, “Understanding and Improving the City: Policy/Research Partnerships in the Digital Age.” More than 200 scholars, public officials, practitioners, students, and civic leaders discussed data-based research-policy collaborations. Panels featuring both scholars and officials explored education, public safety, economic development, and the “civic data ecosystem.” The day concluded with an open discussion on key issues with Boston Mayor Martin J. Walsh.
  • A research seed grant program funding graduate students pursuing pioneering work on novel digital data. The program has supported 10 projects at six different universities. These have been disciplinarily diverse, ranging from analyses of the urban heat island effect, to the demographic and cultural shifts at the turn of the 20th century, to the observation of gentrification through the lens of digital data.
  • The Boston Data Portal has two components: the Boston Data Library and BostonMap. There have been multiple data releases, including curated census data, a database the enables the consistent geographical study of the City of Boston, a library of neighborhood descriptors extracted from administrative data, and 311 reports from across the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, as well as the products of research seed grants. Visitors can download these data, or visualize them on BostonMap, making them accessible to all skill levels. The Boston Data Portal has had more than 70,000 visits to interactive maps and 200 data downloads.
  • The construction of an online network, hosted by LinkedIn, by which over 500 members spanning the range of local universities, public agencies, and private companies can keep informed about new developments in the area of urban research and policy.
